comments: This is a JSON Schema for 'canonical-data.json' files.
It enforces just a general structure for all exercises,
without specifying how the test data should be organized
for each type of test. We do this to keep generality and
allow support for tests the do not fit well in the
The only thing enforced regarding how test data should be
structured is the error encoding, because it was agreed
and it doesn't restrict flexibility in a significant way.
Standardized property names may help when automatically
deriving JSON parsers in some languages, so we followed
a few conventions from the 'Google JSON Style Guide'.
Additionally, this schema strictly enforces letters, in
lowerCamelCase, for naming the 'property' being tested. We
expect this regularity will allow an easier automatic
generation of function's names in test generators,
slightly reducing the amount of manually generated code.

$eref.description: This is the top-level file structure
A single test with a description
A group of tests with a description

_88labeledTestItem.description: A single test or group of tests with a description

_88expected.description: The expected return value of a test case

$eref.description: A message describing an error condition

_88testGroup.description: An array of labeled test items

$eref.description: A single test or group of tests with a description

_88labeledTest.description: A single test with a description

$eref.description: The expected return value of a test case
An array of strings to fake multi-line comments

_88error.description: A message describing an error condition

_88comments.description: An array of strings to fake multi-line comments

_88canonicalData.description: This is the top-level file structure

$eref.description: An array of labeled test items
An array of strings to fake multi-line comments

_88labeledTestGroup.description: A group of tests with a description

$eref.description: An array of labeled test items
An array of strings to fake multi-line comments
